articles.title: APRIL 1988
articles.summary: The April 1988 document outlines a packed schedule of astronomical events, including a general meeting featuring Dr. Martin Walt discussing the U.S. Space Program, a field expedition to Fremont Peak for observation, and a public star party for Astronomy Day. It also details an introductory astronomy class, a board meeting, and announces the upcoming 8th Annual Astronomical Auction in May.

articles.title: FIELD OF VIEW
articles.summary: The article, "FIELD OF VIEW" by John Gleason, announces several upcoming events and club news. It highlights the April 2nd general meeting featuring Dr. Martin Walt discussing the future of the US space program, details the results of recent board elections, and promotes the national Astronomy Day event on April 23rd in San Jose. Additionally, it provides information about the 8th Annual Astronomical Auction scheduled for May 7th in Los Gatos, encouraging early registration for the major event.

articles.title: OOPS!
articles.summary: An announcement titled "OOPS!" informs readers that the A-K portion of the membership list was accidentally omitted from the previous month's bulletin. This missing section will be included in the current month's issue, assuring members that the error has been addressed.

articles.title: ASTRO ADS
articles.summary: This document consists of classified advertisements for amateur astronomers, featuring both 'for sale' and 'wanted' listings. Items include various telescopes (Schmidt-Cassegrain, Refractors, Spotting Scopes) and accessories, all indicating condition and contact information. Additionally, there is a request for photographs of Comet Bradfield's encounter with M10.

articles.title: COMET COMMENTS BY: DON MACHHOLZ
articles.summary: This article provides an update on several comets, noting that only Comet Liller remains brighter than magnitude 11. It details the unusual splitting of Comet Wilson's nucleus in November 1987, four months post-perihelion and at a significant distance from the sun. Additionally, it announces the discovery of three new faint comets: Shoemaker (1988h), Maury-Phinney (1988c), and Periodic Comet Hartley 3 (1988d), along with their discovery details and characteristics.

articles.title: Comet Liller (1988a)
articles.summary: This document provides an ephemeris for Comet Liller (1988a) from late March through early May, including its Right Ascension, Declination, distance, and magnitude. It notes that the comet, despite being technically in the morning sky, is visible all night due to its polar position and suggests it may display a tail in April, remaining visible in binoculars through May.

articles.title: SEEKING COMETS
articles.summary: The article details the author's experiences with media coverage after comet discoveries, noting differences in professionalism and thoroughness among TV, newspaper, and magazine reporters. It also debunks common myths surrounding comet finds, such as receiving numerous photos, gaining significant wealth, achieving widespread fame, or inspiring non-astronomical friends to share the enthusiasm. Ultimately, the author concludes that finding a comet brings little fundamental change to one's life, often contrary to popular expectations, a reality he personally appreciates.

articles.title: BY: RICHARD STANTON
articles.summary: Richard Stanton highlights two upcoming meteor showers for the month. The minor Sigma Leonids are expected to peak on the 17th, with an average speed of 20 km/s and an unpredictable hourly count. Following this, the major Lyrids will reach maximum on the 22nd, known for their faster speed of 48 km/s and an anticipated single observer hourly count of around 15.

articles.title: DAYLIGHT SAVING TIME
articles.summary: This article announces the upcoming start of Daylight Saving Time, requiring clocks to "Spring Forward" one hour on the first Sunday in April (the 3rd) at 2 a.m. It references the Uniform Time Act of 1967 and a 1986 legislation as the basis for this change. The article also provides a practical tip for converting Universal Time to Pacific Daylight Time by deducting 7 hours.

articles.title: GRAZES, OCCULTATIONS & APPULSES
articles.summary: The article details two upcoming celestial events visible from the greater San Francisco Bay Area. On April 23rd at 22:41 PDT, the 7-day-old moon will occult Gemma Cancer (ZC 1308), a 6.67 magnitude star. The following day, the lunar limb will graze the 7.5 magnitude star ZC 1402.

articles.title: LUNAR FEATURES
articles.summary: This article details specific dates and times in April for observing the Lunar Sunset and Sunrise Terminators at prominent lunar features, the Straight Wall and Plato crater. It specifies the Sunset Terminator will cross the Straight Wall on April 10th (00 UT) and Plato two hours later, while the Sunrise Terminator will affect the Straight Wall on April 24th (01 UT) and Plato on April 25th (01 UT). The author also includes a personal anecdote about recent albedo measurements and engages readers with questions about their observing experiences and seeing conditions.

articles.title: VENUS
articles.summary: This month offers an ideal time for a Venus Observing Program, as the planet will achieve maximum altitude high in the western evening sky. Shining brightly at magnitude -4.4, its disc will grow from 22 to 32 arc seconds, with decreasing illumination potentially revealing "cut cusp views." Observers with various telescopes are encouraged to participate and consult a relevant article on the Venus Ashen Light Program.

articles.title: MINOR PLANETS
articles.summary: The article promotes April as an excellent month for asteroid observing and photography, encouraging readers to attempt tracking a minor planet. It provides specific ephemerides for April for three notable minor planets: 04 Vesta, 09 Metis, and 14 Irene, detailing their right ascension, declination, magnitude, and motion for various dates.

articles.title: DEEP SKY
articles.summary: This article highlights the "Black Eye" galaxy (M64) in Coma Bernices as an excellent deep-sky target for spring observations. It provides details on the galaxy's distance, magnitude, and angular size, emphasizing the controversial visual observation of its central dust cloud. The author suggests that the "Black Eye" is within reach of a 6-inch or larger telescope, recommending higher magnification to enhance visibility.

articles.title: PRESIDENT REAGAN'S NATIONAL SPACE POLICY RELEASED
articles.summary: President Reagan's National Space Policy outlines a balanced program for NASA and other federal agencies, aiming for international leadership into the 21st century. It calls for manned flights beyond Earth and a Pathfinder technology program, while also promoting significant commercial involvement through purchasing private space orbit services and leasing private orbiting facilities. The policy further encourages commercial remote sensing by removing restrictions on civilian image resolution.

articles.title: SHUTTLE DISCOVERY IN PROCESSING FOR AUGUST LAUNCH
articles.summary: Space Shuttle Discovery is undergoing final preparations for an August launch, with reinstallation of its thermal protection system almost complete. Key components, including an oxygen propellant line disconnect actuator and high-pressure fuel turbopumps, are scheduled for delivery and certification. The shuttle is slated for transport to the Vehicle Assembly Building and Launch Pad 39B in May, with a flight readiness firing planned for June.

articles.title: SPACE STATION PARTNERS NEARING AGREEMENT
articles.summary: The European Space Agency (ESA) and Canada have finalized an interagency memorandum of understanding for cooperation regarding the Space Station, though details of the broader multilateral intergovernmental agreement are still pending. Japan, however, has not reached an agreement, leading to a cutoff of its budget for access to technical program information.

articles.title: ARIANE PUTS 2 SATELLITES IN ORBIT
articles.summary: On March 11, the ESA successfully launched an Ariane 3 rocket. This mission deployed two communication satellites into geosynchronous orbit, marking a successful orbital placement.

articles.title: JAPANESE ORBIT A COMMUNICATIONS SATELLITE
articles.summary: On February 19, an H-1 booster successfully launched a Japanese communications satellite into geosynchronous orbit, marking another advancement in space technology.

articles.title: NASA'S FY 1989 BUDGET REQUEST
articles.summary: President Reagan has requested an $11.5 billion budget for NASA in FY 1989, a $2.5 billion increase from the previous year. Key allocations include funding for the space station, Advanced X-ray Astrophysics Facility, Pathfinder program, advanced shuttle solid rocket booster, and extended duration orbiter, while the comet rendezvous-asteroid flyby was not approved. However, the article cautions that high budget requests from outgoing presidents often face rejection by the incoming administration and Congress.

articles.title: BOOSTER FOR TITAN 4 TESTED
articles.summary: The second test of a seven-segment solid motor, a booster for the Titan 4 rocket, was conducted on February 14th near San Jose, California. Although initial data indicated success, post-test disassembly revealed missing parts from the carbon-carbon nozzle, prompting an ongoing analysis of the problem. The first Titan 4 launch remains scheduled for late this year.

articles.title: SJAA 1987/1988 MEMBERSHIP ROSTER
articles.summary: This document is the 1987/1988 membership roster for SJAA, listing members with their names and addresses. It appears to be a directory containing contact information for individuals affiliated with the organization during that period.

articles.title: The San Jose Astronomical Association's
articles.summary: The San Jose Astronomical Association is holding its 8th Annual Bay Area Astronomical Auction and Swap-Meet on Saturday, May 7th. The event will take place at the Los Gatos Red Cross building, with the swap-meet running from 2:00 PM to 5:00 PM, followed by the auction from 6:00 PM to 10:00 PM. Participants are encouraged to pre-register items to be auctioned.

articles.title: The 8th Annual Bay Area Astronomical Auction
articles.summary: The 8th Annual Bay Area Astronomical Auction is announced, providing details on how individuals can sell astronomical or telescope-making related items, pre-register for easier processing, and donate items to support public astronomy education through the SJAA. The event will feature a new afternoon Flea Market/Swap-Meet for lower-value or specialized items, in addition to the main auction and a silent bid option for high-ticket items.

articles.title: DIRECTIONS TO THE AUCTION
articles.summary: This document provides detailed directions to an auction event, specifying the address (16011 Los Gatos-Saratoga Rd), opening time (1:00 pm), and a $1.00 registration donation. It also includes a pre-registration form for the 1988 SJAA Auction, allowing individuals to register as bidders and list items for sale.

articles.title: GENERAL MEETINGS
articles.summary: The SJAA holds monthly General Meetings at the Los Gatos Red Cross building in Los Gatos, California. These meetings feature guest speakers discussing various astronomical topics and include "Indoor Star Parties" for members to showcase their projects and interests. Held on the 1st Saturday of each month at 8 PM, these gatherings provide a friendly atmosphere for all astronomy enthusiasts.

articles.title: INDOOR STAR PARTIES
articles.summary: The document describes "Indoor Star Parties" as informal Saturday evening gatherings for amateur astronomers to socialize, discuss astronomy, and share equipment. These events often include outdoor telescope observing, indoor astrophotography slideshows, board meetings, and introductory astronomy workshops, fostering a sense of community among members.

articles.title: FIELD EXPEDITIONS
articles.summary: The San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA) organizes monthly "Star Parties" for astronomical observation on Saturdays closest to the New Moon, held at various locations including Fremont Peak State Park and Yosemite. Fremont Peak is detailed as a popular site for serious deep sky observing and astrophotography, often attracting 50-100 telescopes during clear New Moon weekends. The article also provides information about the SJAA's monthly publication, EPHEMERIS, and a list of current officers and board members.

articles.title: SAN JOSE ASTRONOMICAL ASSOCIATION MEMBERSHIP APPLICATION
articles.summary: This document is a membership application form for the San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA), outlining different membership types and their associated fees, including standard, junior, and options with a Sky & Telescope subscription. It provides instructions for submitting the application and payment by mail to the treasurer or in-person at an SJAA meeting, along with contact details.
